definition:
[**Definition**]{} If $X$ is a set, then the [**identity map**]{} in $X$
is the mapping that maps each element in $X$ to itself.

### Properties

1.  An identity map is always a bijection.

2.  Suppose $X$ has two topologies $\tau_1$ and $\tau_2$. Then the
    identity mapping $I:(X,\tau_1)\to (X,\tau_2)$ is continuous if and
    only if $\tau_1$ is finer than $\tau_2$, i.e.,
    $\tau_1\subset\tau_2$.

3.  The identity map on the $n$-sphere, is to the antipodal map
    $A:S^n\to S^n$ if $n$ is odd [@guillemin].

[9]{} V. Guillemin, A. Pollack, *Differential topology*, Prentice-Hall
Inc., 1974.
